codes.verbatim_quote: Ok, quindi qua le categorie della mia collezione. Ok, quindi ho un journal, 100 journal article. Lo posso ordinare in questo caso: titolo e data di pubblicazione. Ok, 15 issue, 5 volume, 100 manifestation
codes.context: During warm-up exploration, participant systematically enumerates collection categories and counts, demonstrating awareness of data structure

codes.verbatim_quote: Se faccio edit. Ok, posso aggiungere un identificativo, aggiungere l'autore, modificare la data. Va bene
codes.context: Participant tests edit functionality and confirms available modification options

codes.verbatim_quote: E sì, adesso la modifica ovviamente mi creerà uno Snapchat nuovo. Sì, vado alla versione. No, l'ho messo, lo mette ok in automatico, figo
codes.context: Participant understands that modifications automatically create new snapshots in time machine, expressing satisfaction with automatic behavior

codes.verbatim_quote: Qua non posso aggiungere identificativi, non posso aggiungere l'ORCID. Dipende dalla configurazione di SHACL sicuramente
codes.context: When encountering limited field options, participant correctly attributes interface constraints to SHACL configuration

codes.verbatim_quote: Allora, innanzitutto capiamo come è usato. Allora, c'è cartella config, c'è SHACL, non è importante. Allora, c'è journal article, journal article, journal article, journal article shape
codes.context: For Task 1, participant begins by exploring file structure and locating relevant SHACL shape definition before making changes

codes.verbatim_quote: Sarà un sh:property per forza. La metterò, non credo conti l'ordine però mettiamolo sotto titolo
codes.context: Participant assumes property order is not significant while adding abstract property to SHACL, though chooses to place it under title anyway

codes.verbatim_quote: Ok, penso che così va bene
codes.context: Participant expresses confidence in SHACL property addition without extensive verification

codes.verbatim_quote: Perché lì appunto ho aggiunto un campo che è necessario
codes.context: Participant misread task requirements: set sh:minCount 1 (required) instead of 0 (optional) for abstract property, verbalizing belief that field should be mandatory when task specified it should be optional

codes.verbatim_quote: Devo modificare anche l'interfaccia. L'interfaccia la modifico. Dove era? Qua, YAML
codes.context: After adding SHACL property, participant failed to notice 'Add abstract' field appeared in form interface and unnecessarily proceeded to modify YAML display rules

codes.verbatim_quote: Sarà sempre in config. Dobbiamo andare su browser, journal article, display name, journal article, ok. Display properties, credo
codes.context: Participant navigates to YAML configuration file with some uncertainty about exact location within file structure

codes.verbatim_quote: Title. Ok, penso che vada bene. Ecco, abstract, ok
codes.context: Participant uses existing title property as template for adding abstract display rule

codes.verbatim_quote: L'unica cosa è, forse sarebbe utile avere un modo per capire quali risorse sono incomplete a seconda dello schema SHACL che voglio utilizzare
codes.context: Participant identifies missing feature: need for system to flag resources that no longer validate against modified SHACL schema

codes.verbatim_quote: Ok, mi sa che l'avevo già fatto perché ho già messo textarea. Se non sbaglio, eh. Se non sbaglio l'avevo già fatto
codes.context: Participant checks whether textarea configuration was already completed in previous task

codes.verbatim_quote: Hot-reloading for SHACL files: Although the frontend needed a manual refresh, the backend automatically picked up changes, which sped up the trial-and-error process
codes.context: Participant appreciated automatic backend reloading of SHACL changes, which accelerated iterative testing despite requiring manual frontend refresh

codes.verbatim_quote: Inline documentation and examples in the config files: These served as helpful references when editing shapes or display rules
codes.context: Participant found inline documentation and examples within configuration files useful as references during editing tasks

codes.verbatim_quote: I found the documentation clear and beginner-friendly, even for someone without any prior experience with SHACL. The instructions for basic operations like adding properties, setting constraints, and modifying display rules were well explained
codes.context: Participant, with no prior SHACL knowledge, found the documentation clear and accessible for basic configuration operations

codes.verbatim_quote: Lack of contextual help in the UI: For beginners, it would have been helpful if the interface included tooltips or links to documentation next to configurable items
codes.context: Participant identified missing contextual help features in the UI, suggesting tooltips or documentation links would benefit beginners

codes.verbatim_quote: Display rule configuration not fully intuitive: While functional, the way display properties are ordered or grouped isn't immediately obvious, especially without experience
codes.context: Participant found display rule ordering and grouping non-intuitive, confirming uncertainty about implicit configuration rules

codes.verbatim_quote: Visual SHACL editor: A guided interface to add or modify SHACL constraints without needing to edit raw TTL (Turtle) could make the platform more beginner-friendly
codes.context: Participant suggested a visual SHACL editor as an alternative to raw TTL editing to improve accessibility for beginners

codes.verbatim_quote: Validation helper or linter for SHACL files: Something that checks your syntax and constraints before applying them would prevent common mistakes and save time
codes.context: Participant requested a SHACL linter or validator to check syntax and constraints before application, preventing errors and saving time
